title: Why you need a different resume for every job application
summary: One generic resume does not work because Applicant Tracking Systems (ATS) scan for job-specific keywords. Each job posting uses different terminology, so each application needs a resume tailored to that exact job description. ResumeCoach stores your work history once and generates a fresh, keyword-optimized resume for each job you apply to.
bodyText:
ResumeCoach exists because the job market changed. Applicant Tracking Systems now filter resumes before humans see them, scanning for keywords that match the job posting. A generic resume gets auto-rejected because it lacks those specific terms.

The same work experience can be positioned completely differently depending on the role. A sales manager applying for warehouse operations needs inventory and logistics keywords. That same person applying for retail management needs customer experience and merchandising keywords. Same career history, different presentation.

We store your complete work history once. For each job you apply to, we generate a fresh resume using the exact terminology that employer wants. You are not editing one document over and over—you are getting purpose-built resumes.

This is why active job seekers on our Pro plan can generate 10 resumes per month. If you are applying to 25 jobs, you need 25 resumes.
stepsText:
1. Click Upload Resume on the Dashboard or Submit page to upload your resume once.
2. We extract your complete work history, skills, education, and achievements.
3. For each job application, provide a job description or use Job Search to find a listing.
4. We analyze that specific job's requirements using O*NET government data and Indeed market intelligence.
5. Click Create Resume or Submit to generate a new resume with the exact keywords that job requires.
6. Review your SPOR score on the Results page to see how well you match.
7. Edit if needed, download as PDF or Word, and apply.
8. Repeat for your next job—each one gets a fresh, targeted resume from your same work history.

title: What is ATS and why does my resume get rejected
summary: ATS (Applicant Tracking System) is software that 93% of Fortune 500 companies use to scan resumes for keywords before a human sees them. If your resume lacks the right terms from the job posting, it gets auto-rejected regardless of your qualifications. ResumeCoach optimizes your resume with the exact keywords each job's ATS expects.
bodyText:
When you apply for a job online, your resume does not go directly to a recruiter. It goes through ATS software first. This system scans your resume for specific keywords, skills, and qualifications that match the job posting. Resumes are scored and ranked. Only the top-scoring ones (typically top 25%) reach human reviewers.

93% of Fortune 500 companies use ATS. Most mid-size companies do too. If you have applied to dozens of jobs and never heard back, this is likely why—your resume never made it past the robots.

ATS systems are not smart. They do not understand that 'managed a team' means the same as 'supervised staff.' They look for exact keyword matches. If the job posting says 'project management' and your resume says 'led projects,' you might not match.

ResumeCoach solves this by analyzing the job description, identifying the exact keywords the ATS expects, and ensuring your resume contains them. We do not stuff keywords randomly—we rewrite your real experience using the terminology that matches.
stepsText:
1. You submit a job application online through a company website or job board.
2. Your resume enters the company's ATS before any human sees it.
3. ATS scans your resume text for keywords matching the job description.
4. The system scores your resume based on keyword matches, skills alignment, and formatting.
5. Resumes are ranked from highest to lowest match score.
6. Only top-scoring resumes (usually 25% or fewer) are forwarded to recruiters.
7. The rest are automatically rejected—no human ever reviews them.
8. ResumeCoach analyzes job requirements and optimizes your resume to pass these filters.

title: Why the job description is required for resume optimization
summary: The job description contains the exact keywords employers programmed into their ATS filters. Without it, we guess based on general industry standards. With it, we extract specific requirements and match your experience precisely, often achieving 80%+ match scores instead of 60%.
bodyText:
The job description is not optional context—it is the source code for your resume. Every requirement, skill, and qualification listed in that posting was deliberately chosen by the employer. Those same terms are what their ATS scans for.

When you provide a job description, we extract every requirement and cross-reference it against O*NET occupational standards. We identify which of your experiences match and rewrite them using the exact terminology from the posting. The result is a resume that speaks the employer's language.

Without a job description, we can only make educated guesses based on general industry standards. That might get you a 60% match. With the actual posting, we can often achieve 80%+ match scores.

If you do not have the job description, you have options: tell us the job title and we will find a similar one, use our Job Search to find real listings, or describe the role yourself. But a real job posting always produces the best results.
stepsText:
1. Find the job posting on the company website, Indeed, LinkedIn, or other job board.
2. Copy the full job description including requirements, qualifications, and responsibilities.
3. On the Submit page, paste the job description into the Job Description field.
4. We extract every keyword, skill, certification, and requirement mentioned.
5. We cross-reference against O*NET government standards for that occupation.
6. We identify which of your experiences match those requirements.
7. We rewrite your experience using the exact terminology from the posting.
8. Your generated resume now contains the keywords that job's ATS expects.

title: What is SPOR Analysis on the Results page
summary: SPOR stands for Skills, Position, Optimization, and Recommendations. It is our methodology for measuring how well your resume matches a specific job. We analyze your skills fit, experience level, missing keywords, and provide specific improvement advice. Your overall score (0-100) reflects genuine match quality using O*NET government data.
bodyText:
SPOR is not a buzzword—it is a structured analysis framework. Each letter represents a dimension we evaluate:

Skills: Do your listed abilities match what the job requires? We compare against both the job posting and O*NET occupational standards for that role.

Position: Does your experience level fit? We evaluate years of experience, job title progression, and career trajectory against what the role expects.

Optimization: Is your resume formatted for ATS? We check for missing keywords, parsing issues, and formatting problems that could cause rejection.

Recommendations: Based on the above, we provide specific guidance—either resume improvements or honest feedback that you might want to consider alternative roles.

Your overall score (0-100) reflects how well your resume matches that specific job. We do not inflate scores. If you score 45, that is real feedback, not a failure.
stepsText:
1. After submitting your resume, you are redirected to the Results page.
2. Your overall SPOR score (0-100) appears at the top.
3. Skills Analysis shows how your abilities match job requirements and O*NET standards.
4. Position Analysis evaluates your experience level, titles, and career trajectory.
5. Optimization Analysis identifies missing keywords and ATS compatibility issues.
6. Recommendations section provides specific guidance on improvements or alternative roles.
7. Scroll down to see your optimized resume with keywords highlighted.

title: What does my resume score mean on the Results page
summary: Your SPOR score (0-100) honestly reflects how well your resume matches the target job. Scores 70+ mean genuinely qualified. Scores 50-69 mean partial match with gaps. Scores below 50 indicate significant gaps—we explain exactly what is missing and suggest alternatives. A low score is valuable feedback, not failure.
bodyText:
We do not inflate scores to make you feel good. A score of 72 means you are a solid match. A score of 38 means you have significant gaps—and we will tell you exactly what they are.

Score ranges and what they mean:

0-25: Major career pivot territory. Your background is fundamentally different from job requirements. We will suggest alternative roles that fit better.

26-45: Underqualified for this specific role. You are missing critical requirements like degrees, certifications, or years of experience. The feedback explains exactly what gaps exist.

46-65: Partially qualified. You have relevant experience but notable gaps. Your optimized resume helps, but know you are competing against stronger candidates.

66-80: Qualified. You meet most requirements with minor gaps. Your optimized resume has a strong chance of passing ATS.

81-90: Highly qualified. Strong match between your background and requirements.

91-100: Exceptional. You exceed requirements. Ideal candidate profile.

A low score is not an insult—it is information. Better to know before you apply than to wonder why you never hear back.
stepsText:
1. After submission, view your overall score (0-100) on the Results page.
2. Check the breakdown: Skills, Experience, Education, and Keyword Match scores.
3. Read the specific feedback explaining what contributed to your score.
4. For scores below 50: Review the Alternative Roles suggestions we provide.
5. For scores 50-70: Focus on the Improvement Recommendations section.
6. For scores above 70: Your optimized resume is ready—click Edit Resume or Download.

title: What to do if you do not have a job description
summary: You have three options: (1) Enter just the job title and we search Indeed for matching descriptions, (2) Use the Job Search page to find real listings and click Create Resume for This Job, or (3) Describe the role yourself. Real job postings produce better keyword matches than generic titles.
bodyText:
Not having a job description is common. Maybe you are exploring options, or the posting expired, or you just know the general role you want. We have three ways to handle this:

Option A - Job Title Search: Enter the job title (like 'Marketing Manager') and optionally location in the Job Title field on the Submit page. We search Indeed and O*NET for matching job descriptions and use a real one to optimize your resume. This works well for common roles.

Option B - Use Job Search: Click Job Search in the navigation. Browse actual job listings in your area, and click 'Create Resume for This Job' on any listing. We automatically use that job's full description. This is the best option because you get a resume for a real, open position you can actually apply to.

Option C - Describe It Yourself: In the Job Description field on the Submit page, write out the role's responsibilities, required skills, and qualifications. Be specific—the more detail you provide, the better we can optimize. This is the weakest option but works in a pinch.

Why real descriptions work better: Actual job postings contain the exact keywords employers use in their ATS. Generic titles miss these nuances. When possible, use Option A or B.
stepsText:
1. Option A: On the Submit page, enter just the job title (e.g., 'Software Engineer') in the Job Title field.
2. Optionally add location to get more relevant matches from Indeed.
3. Click Submit—we search our database for matching job descriptions from real postings.
4. Option B: Click Job Search in the top navigation menu.
5. Search for positions in your area and click any listing to view details.
6. Click the Create Resume for This Job button to use that listing's description automatically.
7. Option C: On the Submit page, write the role's responsibilities and requirements in the Job Description field.
8. Be as specific as possible—list skills, qualifications, and duties you know the role requires.

title: How to upload your resume using the Upload Resume button
summary: Click the Upload Resume button on the Dashboard or go to the Submit page. Drag and drop your file or click to browse. We accept PDF, DOC, DOCX, and TXT files up to 5MB. Upload completes in under 10 seconds and we extract your work history automatically.

After upload, we parse your resume in about 5-10 seconds. You will see a confirmation with the extracted information. Review it to make sure we captured everything correctly. If something is missing or wrong, you can edit your profile later.

4. Select your resume file (PDF, DOC, DOCX, or TXT format, max 5MB).
5. Wait for the upload progress bar to complete (usually under 10 seconds).
6. Review the extracted information—skills, work history, education.
7. If anything is missing, click Edit Profile to add it manually.
8. Proceed to enter a job description or use Job Search to create your first targeted resume.

title: Supported file formats and size limits for resume upload
summary: We accept PDF, DOC, DOCX, and TXT files up to 5MB. PDF is recommended for best parsing accuracy. If your file fails to upload, try saving it as a different format—for example, export Word documents as PDF.
bodyText:
We support four file formats for resume upload:

PDF (.pdf): Recommended. Best formatting preservation and most reliable parsing.

Word Document (.doc, .docx): Works well. Modern DOCX files parse better than older DOC format.

Plain Text (.txt): Works for simple resumes. All formatting is lost but text content is extracted.

Maximum file size is 5MB. Most resume files are 100KB-500KB, so you should not hit this limit unless your resume contains high-resolution images.

If your file fails to upload or parse correctly, try saving it as a different format. For example, if DOCX fails, try exporting as PDF from Word. If your resume has complex formatting, tables, or graphics, PDF tends to work best.
stepsText:
1. Check your file format: must be PDF, DOC, DOCX, or TXT.
2. Check file size: must be under 5MB (check in file properties).
3. If using PDF, ensure it is not password-protected or encrypted.
4. If using Word, save as DOCX (not older DOC) for better parsing.
5. For complex layouts with tables or graphics, export as PDF from Word.
6. If upload still fails, try the Paste Text option on the Submit page instead.

title: Fix upload failed or file rejected error on Submit page
summary: Upload failures are usually caused by unsupported file types (only PDF/DOC/DOCX/TXT work), files over 5MB, corrupted files, or password-protected PDFs. Try saving as a different format or use the Paste Text option instead.
bodyText:
If your upload fails, check these common causes:

Wrong file type: We only accept PDF, DOC, DOCX, and TXT. Files like JPG, PNG, RTF, or Pages will be rejected with 'Unsupported file type' error.

File too large: Maximum is 5MB. If your resume has embedded images, they might be inflating the file size. Try removing images or compressing the PDF.

Corrupted file: If the file opens normally on your computer but fails here, it might be corrupted during transfer. Try re-saving it and uploading again.

Password-protected PDF: We cannot read encrypted or password-protected PDFs. Remove the password protection before uploading.

Browser issue: Try a different browser (Chrome recommended) or clear your browser cache.

If none of these fix the issue, use the Paste Text tab on the Submit page—copy your resume content and paste it directly.
stepsText:
1. Verify your file is PDF, DOC, DOCX, or TXT format (check the file extension).
2. Right-click the file and check Properties—ensure size is under 5MB.
3. If PDF, try opening it to confirm it is not password-protected.
4. Try opening the file in Word/Preview and re-saving it, then upload again.
5. Try a different browser (Chrome works best) or clear browser cache.
6. If still failing, click the Paste Text tab on the Submit page and paste your resume content directly.
7. If the problem persists, submit a support ticket with: the error message shown, your file format, file size, and browser name.

title: What processing means and how long resume analysis takes
summary: When you see 'Processing' after submitting, we are running SPOR analysis—parsing your resume, analyzing the job description, cross-referencing O*NET data, and generating your optimized resume. This typically takes 30-60 seconds. If stuck over 2 minutes, refresh the page.
bodyText:
When you see 'Processing' after submitting your resume, we are running the SPOR analysis. This involves:

1. Parsing your resume to extract skills, experience, and qualifications
2. Analyzing the job description for requirements and keywords
3. Cross-referencing against O*NET occupational data
4. Generating your optimized resume with matched keywords
5. Calculating your SPOR score

This process typically takes 30-60 seconds. Complex resumes or job descriptions may take slightly longer.

If processing seems stuck (spinner showing for more than 2 minutes), try refreshing the page (F5 or Ctrl+R). Your submission is saved—refreshing will show the results if they completed, or let you know if there was an error.

Do not click Submit multiple times while waiting—this creates duplicate entries and uses your monthly quota.
stepsText:
1. After clicking Submit, you will see a processing indicator (spinner or progress bar).
2. Normal processing time is 30-60 seconds.
3. Wait at least 90 seconds before assuming something is wrong.
4. If stuck over 2 minutes, refresh the page (press F5 or Ctrl+R).
5. After refresh, check Dashboard or Results for your submission.
6. Do not click Submit again while waiting—this creates duplicates.

title: How to improve your resume score on the Results page
summary: To improve your score: provide a complete job description (not just title), ensure your profile lists all relevant skills and achievements with specific numbers, and verify the role matches your experience level. Review the Recommendations section on Results for specific improvement guidance.
bodyText:
Your SPOR score reflects how well your resume matches the specific job. Here is how to improve it:

Provide a better job description: If you used just a job title, find the actual posting and paste the full description. More detail means better keyword matching.

Add missing skills to your profile: Review the feedback on the Results page to see which required skills you are missing. If you have those skills, click Edit Profile to add them.

Expand your achievements: Generic job duties score lower than specific accomplishments with numbers. 'Managed a team' is weaker than 'Managed 12-person team, reduced turnover by 25%.'

Consider role fit: If your score is below 50, the role may require qualifications you do not have (degree, certification, years of experience). The Recommendations section explains what is missing.

Sometimes a low score is accurate feedback that this particular job is not a strong match for your background. That is valuable information before you spend time applying.
stepsText:
1. On the Results page, scroll to the feedback section to see what lowered your score.
2. Check if you provided a complete job description—if not, resubmit with the full posting.
3. Look at the Missing Skills or Gaps section in the feedback.
4. Click Edit Profile to add any skills you have but did not list originally.
5. Add specific numbers and achievements to your work history (e.g., 'increased sales 30%').
6. Click Create New Resume to resubmit with your updated profile.
7. If score is still low, review the Alternative Roles suggestions.

summary: Free plan: 2 resumes/month. Pro ($14.95/mo): 10 resumes. Career Accelerator ($29/mo): 25 resumes. Agency ($79/mo): 100 resumes. Lifetime ($99 one-time): unlimited forever. All paid plans include full SPOR analysis, all download formats, and Job Search access.
bodyText:
ResumeCoach offers plans for different job search intensities:

Free: 2 resume generations per month. Good for trying out the service or occasional use.

Pro ($14.95/month): 10 resumes per month. Best for active job seekers applying to multiple positions weekly.

Career Accelerator ($29/month): 25 resumes per month. For intensive job searches or career changers applying broadly.

Agency ($79/month): 100 resumes per month. For recruiters, career coaches, or staffing agencies.

Lifetime ($99 one-time): Unlimited resumes forever. No monthly fees. Best value if you will use the service long-term.

All paid plans include full SPOR analysis, AI-optimized resumes, all download formats (PDF, Word), and Job Search access. Annual billing is available for Pro and Career Accelerator at 20% discount.
stepsText:
1. Click Pricing in the top navigation to view current plans.
2. Free Plan: 2 resumes per month, basic SPOR analysis.
3. Pro Plan: $14.95/month for 10 resumes per month.
4. Career Accelerator: $29/month for 25 resumes per month.
5. Agency: $79/month for 100 resumes per month.
6. Lifetime: $99 one-time payment for unlimited resumes forever.
7. Click Upgrade or Subscribe on any plan to change your subscription.
8. Annual billing saves 20% on Pro and Career Accelerator plans.

title: How to upgrade your plan from the Billing page
summary: Click Pricing in the navigation or go to Account Settings > Billing. Click Upgrade on your desired plan and enter payment details. The upgrade takes effect immediately—additional resume credits are available right away.
bodyText:
Upgrading your plan is immediate—you get access to additional resume generations right away.

You can upgrade from the Pricing page (click Pricing in navigation) or from Account Settings > Billing.

When you upgrade mid-cycle, you are charged the prorated difference for the remaining days in your billing period. From the next billing cycle, you pay the full new plan price.

If you are on the Free plan and hit your 2-resume limit, you will see an upgrade prompt when trying to create a new resume. Click Upgrade to go directly to plan selection.

Lifetime plan is a one-time purchase that never renews. You get unlimited resumes forever after the single $99 payment.
stepsText:
1. Click Pricing in the top navigation menu.
2. Or go to Account Settings > Billing section.
3. Review the available plans and their resume limits.
4. Click Upgrade or Subscribe on the plan you want.
5. Enter your payment details (credit or debit card).
6. Click Confirm to complete the purchase.
7. Your new plan takes effect immediately—additional resumes available now.
8. For Lifetime plan, you pay once and never see renewal charges.

bodyText:

Lifetime plan cannot be canceled since it is a one-time purchase, not a subscription. There is no recurring billing to stop.

title: Fix account not found or email not recognized error
summary: You may have signed up with a different email or used Google/LinkedIn instead of email registration. Try your other email addresses, try the social login buttons, or use Forgot Password to verify if an email is registered.
bodyText:
If you see 'account not found' or 'email not recognized' when signing in, here are the common causes:

Different email: You may have used a different email address when signing up. Try your other email addresses (personal, work, old email).

Social login mismatch: If you signed up with Google or LinkedIn, you cannot use email/password login. Click Sign in with Google or Sign in with LinkedIn instead.

Typo in email: Double-check for typos in your email address.

No account exists: You may not have completed registration. Try signing up again—if an account exists with that email, you will see an error saying so.

To check if an email is registered, click Forgot Password and enter the email. If registered, you will get a reset link. If not, you will see an error.
stepsText:
1. Try signing in with any other email addresses you use (personal, work, old email).
2. Try clicking Sign in with Google or Sign in with LinkedIn buttons.
3. Double-check your email for typos.
4. Click Forgot Password and enter the email to verify if it is registered.
5. If none of your emails are recognized, you may need to create a new account.
6. If you are certain you have an account but cannot access it, contact support with: the email you believe you used, approximate signup date, and whether you used social login.

title: Data privacy and how ResumeCoach handles your resume
summary: Your resume is encrypted in transit (HTTPS) and at rest on our servers. We never share your data with third parties or employers unless you explicitly apply. Resumes auto-delete after 90 days of inactivity. You can request immediate deletion from Account Settings or by contacting support.
bodyText:
We take your privacy seriously. Here is how we handle your data:

Encryption: All data is transmitted over HTTPS (encrypted in transit) and stored encrypted on our servers (encrypted at rest).

No third-party sharing: We do not sell, rent, or share your resume data with third parties. We do not give your information to recruiters or employers unless you explicitly click Apply and submit to them.

Data retention: Your resumes and profile are retained while your account is active. After 90 days of inactivity (no logins or submissions), data is automatically deleted. Active accounts retain data indefinitely.

Deletion requests: You can request immediate deletion of your data from Account Settings > Privacy, or by contacting support. We process deletion requests within 7 days.

What we use data for: Generating your optimized resumes and improving our AI models (anonymized and aggregated only).
stepsText:
1. All uploads and data transfer use HTTPS encryption.
2. Stored data is encrypted at rest on secure servers.
3. We never share your data with third parties or employers without your action.
4. Data auto-deletes after 90 days of account inactivity.
5. To request manual deletion: go to Account Settings > Privacy.
6. Or email support requesting account and data deletion.
7. Deletion is processed within 7 days of request.

title: Fix white screen or blank page not loading
summary: A blank page usually means a browser compatibility issue. Try: hard refresh (Ctrl+Shift+R on Windows, Cmd+Shift+R on Mac), clear browser cache, disable extensions (especially ad blockers), try Incognito mode, or use Chrome browser.
bodyText:
If you see a white screen or blank page where content should appear, this is usually a browser issue, not a server problem.

First, try a hard refresh: Press Ctrl+Shift+R on Windows or Cmd+Shift+R on Mac. This forces the browser to reload everything fresh without cache.

If that does not work, clear your browser cache and cookies for resumecoach.me, then reload.

Browser extensions (especially ad blockers, privacy extensions, or VPN extensions) can sometimes break web apps. Try disabling extensions or opening the site in Incognito/Private mode where extensions are disabled by default.

If the problem persists, try a different browser. Chrome is recommended and most thoroughly tested.

If you have tried all the above and still see a blank page, it may be a more serious issue requiring support investigation.
stepsText:
1. Hard refresh: Press Ctrl+Shift+R (Windows) or Cmd+Shift+R (Mac).
2. Clear browser cache and cookies for resumecoach.me.
3. Disable browser extensions, especially ad blockers and privacy tools.
4. Try opening the site in Incognito or Private browsing mode.
5. Try a different browser (Chrome recommended).
6. If still blank, press F12 to open developer tools, click Console tab, look for red error messages.
7. If problem persists, submit a support ticket with: your browser name and version, device type (desktop/mobile), screenshot of the blank page, and any red error messages from the Console.

title: Fix stuck spinning or loading forever after Submit
summary: Normal processing takes 30-60 seconds. If stuck loading over 2 minutes: refresh the page (F5), check your internet connection, try a different browser. Do not click Submit again—this creates duplicates. Your submission is saved and will appear on Dashboard.
bodyText:
If you see a spinner or loading indicator that will not stop, first make sure you have waited long enough. Normal resume processing takes 30-60 seconds. Wait at least 90 seconds before assuming it is stuck.

If still spinning after 2 minutes:

Refresh the page: Press F5 or Ctrl+R. Your submission is saved—refreshing will show results if they completed, or show the Dashboard if still processing.

Check your internet connection: Try loading another website to confirm you are online.

Try a different browser: Some older browsers or those with many extensions can cause issues. Chrome is recommended.

Do not click Submit again while waiting. This creates duplicate entries and wastes your monthly resume quota.

If the problem keeps happening, there may be a temporary server issue.
stepsText:
1. Wait at least 90 seconds—normal processing takes 30-60 seconds.
2. If stuck over 2 minutes, refresh the page (press F5 or Ctrl+R).
3. Check your internet connection by loading another website.
4. Try a different browser (Chrome recommended).
5. Do NOT click Submit again—this creates duplicate entries.
6. After refresh, check Dashboard or Results for your submission.
7. If problem persists, submit a support ticket with: the page URL, what you were submitting, how long you waited, and your browser/device info.

title: Fix 500 error or Something went wrong server error
summary: A 500 error means something went wrong on our servers—not caused by you. Wait 2-3 minutes and try again. If it persists over 10 minutes, submit a support ticket with: the exact URL, what action you attempted, the time it happened, and the full error message.
bodyText:
A 500 error (or 'Internal Server Error' or 'Something went wrong') means an unexpected problem occurred on our servers. This is not caused by anything you did.

Most 500 errors are temporary glitches. Wait 2-3 minutes and try your action again. The issue often resolves itself.

If the error persists after 10 minutes, there may be a larger service issue.

Do not repeatedly retry the same action in quick succession—this can make server issues worse.

Clearing your browser cache and trying again sometimes helps if the error is caused by stale cached data.
stepsText:
1. Wait 2-3 minutes, then try the same action again.
2. If still failing, clear your browser cache and try again.
3. Try a different browser to rule out browser-specific issues.
4. Check if other parts of the site work (can you load Dashboard?).
5. If error persists over 10 minutes, submit a support ticket.
6. Include in your ticket: the exact URL where the error occurred, what action you were trying to do, the approximate time, and the full error message text or a screenshot.

A 404 error means the URL you requested does not exist on our site. This is usually caused by:

Typo in the URL: Double-check the address bar for mistakes or extra characters.

Outdated bookmark: If you bookmarked a page previously, it may have moved or been renamed. Delete the old bookmark and navigate fresh from the Dashboard.

Old link: Links from old emails or external sites may point to pages that no longer exist or have changed URLs.

Deleted content: If you are trying to access an old resume that was deleted (after 90 days of inactivity), it will 404.

title: Fix failed to fetch or connection error
summary: Connection errors usually mean a network issue on your end or temporary server maintenance. Check your internet, disable VPN if using one, try a different network (WiFi vs mobile data), and retry in a few minutes.
bodyText:
A 'Failed to fetch' or 'connection error' or 'network error' typically means the request could not reach our servers. This is usually a network issue rather than a problem with the site itself.

Check your internet connection: Can you load other websites like google.com? If not, the issue is your network, not us.

Disable VPN: Some VPNs block or slow connections to certain services. Try disconnecting your VPN and retrying.

Try a different network: Switch from WiFi to mobile data (or vice versa) to rule out local network issues.

Wait and retry: If our servers are briefly overloaded or undergoing maintenance, waiting a few minutes usually resolves it.

If the problem persists across different networks and browsers, there may be an outage on our end.
stepsText:
1. Check if other websites load—open google.com to confirm your internet works.
2. Disable VPN if you are using one.
3. Try a different network—switch from WiFi to mobile data or vice versa.
4. Wait a few minutes and try again.
5. Try a different browser.
6. If still failing across multiple networks and browsers, there may be a service outage.
7. Submit a support ticket with: your location (country/region), internet provider if known, the action you were trying, and the exact error message.

title: How to download your resume as PDF or Word from the Results page
summary: From the Results page, click the Download button and choose PDF or Word (DOCX) format. PDF is best for online applications and email. Word is best if you need to make additional edits in Microsoft Word or Google Docs.
bodyText:
Once your resume is generated and you have made any edits, you can download it in multiple formats.

PDF format (.pdf): Best for submitting to online application systems, emailing to recruiters, or uploading to job boards. PDF preserves exact formatting and fonts across all devices. Most ATS systems can parse PDF files.

Word format (.docx): Best if you want to make additional edits in Microsoft Word, Google Docs, or other word processors. Also useful if an employer specifically requests a Word document.

The download starts immediately after you select your format. Check your browser's download folder or the bottom of your browser window for the file.

You can download the same resume multiple times in different formats if needed.

2. Make any edits using the Edit Resume button if needed.
3. Click the Download button.
4. Choose your format: PDF or Word (DOCX).
5. The file downloads to your computer immediately.
6. Check your Downloads folder or browser download bar for the file.
7. You can download again in a different format if needed.

title: When to use PDF vs Word format for your resume download
summary: Use PDF for online applications, email submissions, and job boards—it preserves formatting perfectly. Use Word (DOCX) if you need to make additional edits or if an employer specifically requests Word format. Most ATS systems accept both formats.
bodyText:
Both PDF and Word formats work for job applications, but each has advantages:

Choose PDF when:
- Submitting through online application portals
- Emailing directly to recruiters or hiring managers
- Uploading to job boards like Indeed or LinkedIn
- You want guaranteed formatting (fonts, spacing, layout stay exactly as designed)
- You do not need to make further edits

Choose Word (DOCX) when:
- The employer specifically requests Word format
- You want to make additional edits in Microsoft Word or Google Docs
- A recruiter asks for an editable version
- You plan to customize further before each application

ATS compatibility: Modern ATS systems can parse both PDF and Word files. However, some older systems handle Word slightly better. When in doubt, check if the application portal specifies a preferred format.

You can always download both versions and use whichever fits each application.
stepsText:
1. For most online applications: Download as PDF.
2. For email submissions to recruiters: Download as PDF.
3. If employer requests Word specifically: Download as Word (DOCX).
4. If you need to edit more in Word or Google Docs: Download as Word.
5. When unsure: Download both formats and choose per application.
6. Check application portal for any specified format preference.

3. Make any final edits if needed

After clicking Apply:

2. Follow their application instructions
3. Upload your downloaded resume when prompted
4. Fill out any additional required fields
5. Submit through their system

The Apply button is a convenience link—it saves you from searching for the application page separately.

title: How to view and track your job applications on the Dashboard
summary: The Dashboard shows all your resume submissions organized by job. Each card shows the job title, company, your SPOR score, and submission date. Click any card to view the full results, edit the resume, or download again.
bodyText:
Your Dashboard is the central hub for managing all your job applications. Every resume you generate is saved here and linked to the specific job it was created for.

Each submission appears as a card showing:
- Job title and company name
- Your SPOR score for that application
- Date you created the resume
- Status if you have applied

Click any card to view the full Results page for that submission. From there you can:
- Review the detailed SPOR analysis
- Edit the resume further
- Download again in PDF or Word
- Click Apply if you have not submitted yet

The Dashboard helps you track which jobs you have applied to and compare your match scores across different positions. If you are applying to many jobs, this keeps everything organized.

Resumes are retained while your account is active. After 90 days of inactivity, data may be automatically deleted.
stepsText:
1. Click Dashboard in the top navigation menu.
2. View your list of resume submissions as cards.
3. Each card shows: job title, company, SPOR score, date.
4. Click any card to open the full Results page for that job.
5. From Results, you can edit, download, or apply.
6. Use Dashboard to compare scores across different applications.
7. Track which jobs you have already applied to.

title: How to access and reuse a previous resume from the Dashboard
summary: Go to the Dashboard to see all your previous resume submissions. Click any card to open that resume. You can view the results, edit it again, download it in PDF or Word, or use it as reference for a new application.
bodyText:
All your generated resumes are saved and accessible from the Dashboard. You do not need to regenerate a resume to access it again.

To find a previous resume:
1. Go to Dashboard from the navigation menu
2. Scroll through your submission cards
3. Cards are sorted by date with most recent first
4. Click the card for the job you want

Once you open a previous resume, you have full access:
- View the original SPOR score and analysis
- Edit the resume content (changes save to that version)
- Download again as PDF or Word
- Click Apply if you haven't submitted yet

Note: Each resume is tied to the specific job description it was created for. If you want to apply to a different job, you should create a new resume for that job to get proper keyword optimization. Reusing an old resume for a different job will likely result in lower ATS match rates.
stepsText:
1. Click Dashboard in the top navigation.
2. Scroll to find the resume you want (sorted by date, newest first).
3. Click the card to open that resume's Results page.
4. View the SPOR score and analysis from that submission.
5. Click Edit Resume to make changes to that version.
6. Click Download to get the PDF or Word file again.
7. For a new job, create a new resume rather than reusing an old one.

title: How to create a new resume for a different job from your existing profile
summary: From the Dashboard, click New Resume or Create New to start a new submission. Your work history is already saved in your profile—just enter a new job description or use Job Search to find a new listing. We generate a fresh resume optimized for that different job.
bodyText:
Once you have uploaded your resume once, your work history is saved in your profile. You do not need to upload again for each new application. Just provide a new job description and we generate a fresh, optimized resume.

This is the core workflow for active job seekers:
1. Your profile contains your base work history, skills, and education
2. For each job you want to apply to, you provide a different job description
3. We analyze that specific job's requirements
4. We generate a new resume tailored to that job's keywords
5. Each resume is saved separately on your Dashboard

You can create as many resumes as your plan allows (Free: 2/month, Pro: 10/month, etc.). Each one is uniquely optimized for its target job.

If your work history has changed (new job, new skills, new certification), update your profile before creating new resumes so the new information is included.
stepsText:
1. From the Dashboard, click New Resume or Create New button.
2. You are taken to the Submit page with your profile already loaded.
3. Enter a new job description for the job you want to apply to.
4. Or click Job Search to find a listing and use its description.
5. Click Submit to generate a resume optimized for this new job.
6. Wait 30-60 seconds for processing.
7. View your new SPOR score and optimized resume on Results.
8. Repeat for each job you want to apply to.

title: Fix Resume Editor not saving or changes lost
summary: Changes in the Resume Editor should save automatically as you type. If changes are not saving: check your internet connection, wait a few seconds for the 'Saved' indicator, and avoid navigating away before saving completes. Try refreshing the page and making edits again.
bodyText:
The Resume Editor auto-saves your changes as you type. You should see a 'Saved' or 'Saving...' indicator when changes are being saved. If your edits are being lost, here are common causes and fixes:

Internet connection dropped: The editor needs an active connection to save. Check if other websites load. If your connection dropped mid-edit, your changes may not have saved.

Navigated away too quickly: If you leave the editor page before saving completes, changes may be lost. Wait for the 'Saved' indicator before clicking away.

Browser issue: Try refreshing the page and editing again. If the problem persists, try a different browser (Chrome recommended).

Session expired: If you were inactive for a long time, your session may have expired. Sign in again and retry.

If you continue having problems, you can always download your resume, make edits in Word or Google Docs, and use that edited version for applications.
stepsText:
1. Check your internet connection—try loading another website.
2. Look for the 'Saved' or 'Saving...' indicator in the editor.
3. Wait a few seconds after each edit for saving to complete.
4. Do not navigate away or close the tab while 'Saving...' is shown.
5. If changes were lost, refresh the page and try editing again.
6. Try a different browser (Chrome recommended).
7. If problem persists, download the resume and edit in Word instead.
8. If this still does not work, click Report bug or the support chat icon and include: your browser name, what edits you tried to make, and any error messages shown.

title: How to update your profile and work history
summary: Click your profile icon and select Edit Profile, or look for Profile or Account Settings. You can add new jobs, update skills, add certifications, and edit education. Updated information will be used in all future resume generations.
bodyText:
Your profile stores your base work history that we use to generate targeted resumes. When your career changes—new job, new skills, new certification—you should update your profile so future resumes include that information.

What you can update:
- Work experience: Add new jobs, edit titles, update descriptions, add achievements
- Skills: Add new skills, remove outdated ones, reorder by importance
- Education: Add degrees, certifications, training programs
- Contact info: Update phone, email, location, LinkedIn URL

When to update:
- You started a new job
- You earned a new certification or degree
- You learned new skills
- You want to add achievements you previously forgot
- Your contact information changed

After updating your profile, any new resumes you create will include the updated information. Existing resumes on your Dashboard are not automatically updated—they keep the information from when they were created.
stepsText:
1. Click your profile icon or name in the top right corner.
2. Select Edit Profile or Profile Settings from the menu.
3. Or look for Profile or Account Settings in the navigation.
4. Find the section you want to update: Experience, Skills, Education, or Contact.
5. Click Edit or the pencil icon next to the section.
6. Make your changes and click Save.
7. New resumes will use your updated information.
8. Existing resumes on Dashboard keep their original information.

title: Understanding your Before Score vs After Score comparison
summary: The Before Score shows how your original resume matched the job. The After Score shows how your optimized resume matches. The difference demonstrates the improvement from our keyword optimization. A 25-point improvement is typical.
bodyText:
On the Results page, you may see two scores: Before and After (or Original vs Optimized). This comparison shows the impact of our optimization.

Before Score: How well your original uploaded resume matched the job requirements. This score reflects your resume as-is, with whatever keywords and phrasing you used.

After Score: How well your optimized resume matches the job. This score reflects the resume after we have added missing keywords, rephrased experience to match job terminology, and improved ATS compatibility.

The difference between these scores shows what our optimization accomplished. Typical improvements:
- 15-25 point improvement: Good optimization, common for resumes that were already decent
- 25-40 point improvement: Significant optimization, common for resumes missing key terminology
- 40+ point improvement: Major transformation, usually when the original resume was generic

If both scores are low (under 50), the job may simply not be a strong match for your background. No amount of keyword optimization can create experience you do not have.
stepsText:
1. On the Results page, look for the score comparison section.
2. Before Score shows your original resume's match.
3. After Score shows your optimized resume's match.
4. The difference shows the improvement from optimization.
5. 15-25 point improvement is typical.
6. If After Score is still low, the job may not match your experience.
7. Review the feedback section for specific gap explanations.

title: Understanding the consultative advice in your SPOR report
summary: The Recommendations section of your SPOR report provides personalized career guidance. This may include alternative roles that fit your background better, skills to develop, or honest feedback about experience gaps. We give practical advice, not just scores.
bodyText:
Beyond scores, your SPOR report includes consultative advice tailored to your specific situation. This appears in the Recommendations section.

Types of advice you may see:

Alternative roles: If your score is low for the target job, we suggest related roles where your background is a stronger match. A marketing coordinator applying for CMO might see suggestions for Marketing Manager or Senior Marketing Specialist.

Skill gaps to address: We identify skills the job requires that you do not have listed. Some can be added to your profile if you have them. Others are development opportunities.

Experience positioning: Suggestions for how to better describe your experience to match industry terminology.

Honest assessment: If the role requires qualifications you cannot quickly obtain (specific degree, 10 years of experience when you have 3), we tell you directly. Better to know before investing time in an application.

This is not generic advice. It is based on comparing your specific background against the specific job requirements using O*NET occupational standards.
stepsText:
1. On the Results page, scroll to the Recommendations section.
2. Read alternative role suggestions if your score is low.
3. Review skill gaps—add to your profile if you have them but did not list.
4. Note experience positioning tips for future applications.
5. Take honest assessments seriously—they can save you application time.
6. Click suggested alternative roles to search for those jobs instead.

title: Where ResumeCoach gets job data and market intelligence
summary: We use three authoritative sources: O*NET (U.S. Department of Labor occupational database), Indeed (real-time job market data), and CareerOneStop (government career resources). This ensures our keyword recommendations reflect actual employer requirements, not guesswork.
bodyText:
ResumeCoach does not guess what employers want. We use authoritative data sources to understand job requirements:

O*NET (Occupational Information Network): The U.S. Department of Labor's comprehensive database of occupational information. Contains detailed data on skills, knowledge, abilities, and tasks for over 1,000 occupations. This is the gold standard for understanding what each role actually requires.

Indeed Job Market Data: Real-time job posting data showing what employers are actually asking for in current listings. This captures emerging skills and trending terminology that may not yet be in government databases.

CareerOneStop: Another government resource providing career exploration data, salary information, and industry trends. Helps validate that our recommendations align with labor market realities.

When you submit a job description, we cross-reference it against these sources to:
- Validate the stated requirements against industry norms
- Identify standard keywords for that occupation
- Ensure we are not missing critical terms
- Provide accurate alternative role suggestions

This data-driven approach means your optimized resume reflects what employers actually look for, not what we assume they want.
stepsText:
1. O*NET provides occupational standards from the U.S. Department of Labor.
2. Indeed provides real-time job market data and current listings.
3. CareerOneStop provides government career resources and trends.
4. We cross-reference your job description against these sources.
5. This validates requirements against industry norms.
6. Keywords we add are based on actual employer usage.
7. Alternative role suggestions come from occupational relationships in O*NET.

title: Understanding your base resume vs generated resumes
summary: Your base resume is the original you uploaded—it becomes your profile storing all your facts (jobs, dates, achievements). Generated resumes are the targeted versions we create for each job application, using your base data but optimized with job-specific keywords.
bodyText:
There is an important distinction between your base resume and generated resumes:

Base Resume / Profile:
- The original resume you uploaded
- Contains your factual information: job titles, companies, dates, achievements, skills, education
- Stored in your profile
- Used as the source material for all generated resumes
- You can update it anytime to add new jobs or skills

Generated Resumes:
- Created fresh for each job you apply to
- Uses your base resume facts but rewrites them with job-specific keywords
- Each one is different, optimized for that particular job description
- Saved on your Dashboard linked to the job it was created for
- You can have many generated resumes (one per job application)

Think of your base resume as ingredients, and each generated resume as a dish prepared for a specific occasion. Same core ingredients, different preparation based on what is needed.

When you update your profile, you are updating the ingredients. New generated resumes will use the updated ingredients. Old generated resumes stay as they were.
stepsText:
1. Your base resume is uploaded once and becomes your profile.
2. It stores all your factual information: jobs, dates, skills, education.
3. Generated resumes are created for each job application.
4. Each generated resume uses your profile data but optimizes for that job.
5. You can have many generated resumes (one per job).
6. Update your profile to add new information for future resumes.
7. Existing generated resumes keep their original content.

title: How to use Paste Text when you cannot upload a file
summary: On the Submit page, click the Paste Text tab instead of Upload. Copy all text from your resume document and paste it into the text area. This works when file upload fails or you only have a text version of your resume.
bodyText:
If you cannot upload a file—maybe it keeps failing, or you only have your resume as plain text—you can paste the content directly instead.

The Paste Text option extracts your work history from plain text just like file upload does. You lose formatting (fonts, columns, styling) but all the actual content is preserved.

When to use Paste Text:
- File upload keeps failing
- Your resume is in a format we do not support (like Pages or RTF)
- You only have the text content, not the original file
- You want to quickly test with partial resume content

How to prepare your text:
- Open your resume in any application
- Select All (Ctrl+A or Cmd+A)
- Copy (Ctrl+C or Cmd+C)
- Make sure you got everything—job titles, dates, descriptions, skills, education

Paste into our text area and submit. We parse the text the same way we parse uploaded files.
stepsText:
1. On the Submit page, look for the Paste Text or Text tab (near Upload).
2. Click to switch to text input mode.
3. Open your resume in Word, Google Docs, or any text editor.
4. Select all content: Ctrl+A (Windows) or Cmd+A (Mac).
5. Copy: Ctrl+C (Windows) or Cmd+C (Mac).
6. Click in the text area on the Submit page.
7. Paste: Ctrl+V (Windows) or Cmd+V (Mac).
8. Review that all content pasted correctly.
9. Click Submit to process your resume.

title: Fix downloaded resume has wrong formatting or looks different
summary: Downloaded PDFs should preserve formatting exactly. If formatting looks wrong: try downloading PDF instead of Word, open Word files in Microsoft Word (not Google Docs or Preview), and check that you are viewing at 100% zoom. Some formatting differences in Word are expected.
bodyText:
If your downloaded resume looks different than expected, here are common causes and fixes:

PDF looks wrong:
- PDF should preserve exact formatting. If it looks wrong, try refreshing the page and downloading again.
- Make sure you are opening the PDF in a proper PDF reader (Adobe Acrobat, Preview, browser), not trying to edit it in Word.

Word (DOCX) looks wrong:
- Some formatting differences in Word are expected. Our templates are optimized for PDF output.
- Open in Microsoft Word specifically. Google Docs, Apple Pages, or LibreOffice may display differently.
- Fonts may substitute if you do not have the exact fonts installed. This is normal.

Layout issues:
- Check that you are viewing at 100% zoom. Weird zoom levels can make formatting look off.
- If downloaded multiple times, make sure you are opening the most recent file.

If you need exact formatting, always use PDF. Word is for when you need to make additional edits, with the understanding that some styling may need adjustment.
stepsText:
1. For exact formatting, download as PDF (not Word).
2. Open PDFs in a proper reader: Adobe Acrobat, Preview, or browser.
3. If using Word format, open in Microsoft Word specifically.
4. Google Docs or other apps may display Word files differently.
5. Check your view zoom is at 100%.
6. If fonts look wrong in Word, this is normal font substitution.
7. Try refreshing the page and downloading a fresh copy.
8. If this still does not work, click Report bug or the support chat icon and include: which format you downloaded, what looks wrong (screenshot helps), and what application you opened it in.

title: Fix job search showing no results or wrong results
summary: If Job Search returns no results: try broader search terms, check your spelling, use common job titles, and try a larger location area. If results seem wrong, the search uses Google Jobs which may include related roles.
bodyText:
If Job Search is not returning the results you expect, here are common issues and fixes:

No results found:
- Try broader search terms. 'Software Engineer' finds more than 'Senior Backend Python Engineer.'
- Check spelling of job title and location.
- Use a larger geographic area. Try state instead of city, or increase the radius.
- Very niche roles may have few current openings.

Wrong or irrelevant results:
- Job Search uses Google Jobs, which may include related roles.
- A search for 'Manager' might return various types of management roles.
- Be more specific: 'Restaurant Manager' instead of just 'Manager.'

Outdated listings:
- Google Jobs aggregates from many sources. Some listings may be slightly outdated.
- Always verify on the employer's actual website before applying.

The job search is meant to help you find real job descriptions to use for resume optimization. If you already have a job description from another source, you can paste it directly on the Submit page instead.
stepsText:
1. Try broader, more common job titles.
2. Check spelling of job title and location.
3. Use a larger location: state, region, or remote.
4. If too many irrelevant results, make your search more specific.
5. Results come from Google Jobs and may include related roles.
6. Verify listings on the employer website before applying.
7. If you have a job description already, paste it on Submit page instead.
8. If this still does not work, click Report bug or the support chat icon and include: what you searched for, your location, and what happened.

title: What happens to my resume after 90 days of inactivity
summary: Resumes and profile data auto-delete after 90 days of account inactivity (no logins or submissions). To prevent deletion, simply log in periodically. Active accounts retain data indefinitely. You can manually request deletion anytime from Account Settings.
bodyText:
To protect your privacy and manage data responsibly, we automatically delete data from inactive accounts.

The 90-day inactivity policy:
- If you do not log in or submit any resumes for 90 consecutive days, your data may be deleted.
- This includes your profile, all generated resumes, and account preferences.
- You will receive an email warning before deletion if you provided a valid email.

How to prevent automatic deletion:
- Simply log in to your account at least once every 90 days.
- Any login activity resets the inactivity timer.
- Submitting a new resume also counts as activity.

Active accounts:
- If you log in regularly, your data is retained indefinitely.
- There is no limit to how long we will store your resumes for active accounts.

Manual deletion:
- You can request immediate deletion of all your data anytime.
- Go to Account Settings > Privacy or contact support.
- Manual deletion requests are processed within 7 days.

If you are job searching sporadically, just remember to log in occasionally to keep your data.
stepsText:
1. Data auto-deletes after 90 days of no logins or submissions.
2. To prevent deletion, log in at least once every 90 days.
3. Any activity (login, submission) resets the inactivity timer.
4. Active accounts keep data indefinitely.
5. You will get an email warning before auto-deletion.
6. To delete data immediately: Account Settings > Privacy > Delete Data.
7. Or contact support to request account deletion.
